Good game - not a great game.

The survival foundations, automation, combat are all good. The first 40 hours are a good loop where you grow your character through combat, exploration and building. The combat is made fun by good animations and weapon variety, and there's a nice sense of progression as your power in combat increases as you unlock new things.

Then it flatlines. Increases in combat difficulty come from bloating health bars. No new mechanics, and copy pasted and reskinned enemies.

Your base automation doesn't grow in complexity, it just adds higher tiers of the same simple recipes. The payoff is slightly higher stats to offset the 'bullet sponge' enemies. The depth of crafting is nonexistant, your pallet to build more interesting things doesn't increase. It's just reskinned,

As a sidenote, the game is aweful with default configuration. Progression is too slow and you have to grind things that are not interesting enough to engage with. One of the most egregious is repeated dungeons with identical monsters that can only take 'blunt' damage and prevent all combo moves. So you find yourself clicking basic attack for 10 minutes with occasional dodge to down the enemies. That's the game at it's worst, and it's aweful.

It's worth the money, I had a good 40 hours and another 'maybe it get's better?' 25. But near mid to end game, even after adjusting 30-40 of the settings, becomes not fun. Buy it, but don't expect to finish it. The end game is reskinned and makes the issues in the first half more glaring.

After spending a good chunk of time with Soulmask, I can confidently say this game is a fantastic addition to the survival genre. If you’ve ever wanted a game that feels like a blend of Conan Exiles, Valheim, Green Hell, Necesse, and Palworld, then Soulmask is exactly what you’re looking for and then some.

At first glance, Soulmask looks like your typical survival game: gather resources, craft weapons, build a base, and fend off enemies. But what sets it apart is the mask system. A mysterious power that lets you take control of other characters, expanding your options for managing a tribe, commanding workers, and fighting smarter. It adds a unique layer of strategy and progression that makes you feel like more than just another scavenger in the wild.

The setting is absolutely gorgeous, but don’t let that fool you it’s also merciless. Everything from wild animals to barbarians to your own poor planning can wipe you out. The game strikes a fine balance between difficult and rewarding, forcing you to adapt, plan, and learn from your mistakes rather than brute force your way through.

The ability to recruit and manage NPCs is both a blessing and a curse. On one hand, it’s amazing to delegate tasks like gathering, farming, and defending your base. On the other, NPCs can sometimes feel like adorable yet infuriating toddlers, forgetting how to do basic tasks or standing around while a jaguar mauls them. It’s a work in progress, but when it works, it makes the game feel like a living, breathing society.

The combat is fast, brutal, and satisfying. It has a mix of melee, ranged, and tactical options that encourage smart fighting rather than button mashing. Blocking, parrying, stunning, sneak attacking, executing, and dodge rolling to name a few all help flesh the system out quite a bit.

Exploring the world is equally engaging, with hidden ruins, dangerous territories, and the constant thrill of discovery. The game rewards risk takers, and every adventure feels like it could be your last… because sometimes, it is…

Soulmask is an addictive, immersive, and incredibly fun survival experience. It takes the best elements of other survival games, mixes them into something fresh, and delivers a world that constantly challenges you. While there are some rough edges, the foundation here is solid, and if the developers keep improving it, this could become one of the best survival games in years.

If you love difficult but rewarding survival games, building and managing your own tribe, and occasionally turning poop into bombs (yes, really), Soulmask is absolutely worth playing.

I know it’s a survival game and it’s still in early access, but starting out with no real goal besides a flood of tutorials and information—even the UI is overwhelming at first—can easily push players away. There’s no real introduction to the story (if there even is one). And that opening cutscene? For me, it explains absolutely nothing. I get that it’s a survival game, but many survival games still have some kind of story setup, world introduction, or at least an explanation of who you are and why you're even here.

The crafting menu also isn’t great. I appreciate the attempt to divide knowledge into “sections,” but it doesn’t help much when you’re still being flooded with a massive list of items. It would be much better if everything was separated into clearly defined windows/categories.

The animations are so stiff it’s honestly painful to look at. The transitions between them… ugh. Just try chopping a tree and moving your mouse—the character suddenly “teleports” into a new position. Or if your character dies underwater, they start crawling. Crawling! Underwater. The same goes for facial expressions: there basically aren’t any, and characters look like empty dolls.

Combat is also pretty mediocre. The animations aren’t great (same issue as above), and enemies feel super stiff too—they mostly just stare at you, waiting for you to make a move, and sometimes they hit you… maybe. In most games, combat feels enjoyable to me, but here it really doesn’t.

I even jumped into the water expecting some sharks or something interesting, but nope—just empty space where you can swim and swim and swim and… swim.

As for graphics, they’re nice and pleasant to look at. I enjoyed running around the map, but that leads to another issue: the map is big, but mostly empty, aside from a few animals. (Maybe that’s because I didn’t explore much beyond the starting zone, but honestly the game didn’t motivate me to go further.) Most of my time was spent running around aimlessly.

Now, the character creator… look, I know it’s early access, but considering how extremely limited it is, it’s hard to say anything positive. But hey, they added jiggle physics for breasts… Great right... I guess. Personally, in actual state I’d prefer just two preset characters—one male and one female—but actually well polished. Maybe the character creator will improve later and give us more options.

There’s also no first-person mode. If I can’t make my character look the way I want, then I’d rather not stare at her and would prefer a first-person view instead.

The building mode is a so much pain. There’s absolutely no button to lower or raise foundations — you have to dance around to position things properly and wiggle the camera. When i love building in almost every game, that here. No way!

So overall, the game didn’t grab my attention or hook me enough with its beginning for me to want to come back to it. Maybe I’ll give it another try someday when I run out of other games to play, but for now… it’s just boring.

Unique background of amazonian jungle with interesting feature about AI tribesman you capture to order them doing certain tasks so you have a semi-living-village-like experience. There's not much to build, but models are well designed and fit together perfectly, so even simple constructions look good. When I bought the game I had an impression THIS is solid foundation developers will further build on - now knowing there is no further developement - as a whole game, it lacks much. Interesting surface, not much deepness.

There are many ways you can tweak and balance gameplay by "server settings", so that's a welcome feature, especially for solo players.

Overall Soulmask is fine example of a game that goes through the checklist of what supposed to be in a game from this genre, checks most marks as "it's there" and that's it. There is a lot of bland content that will keep you busy for hours. For me AI tribesmen is only feature that makes this game interesting, but when everything else is meh, playing Soulmask felt like forcing myself to do meh things in order to enjoy one particular feature for a while.

If you want one perfect example of Soulmask bland content, the Jaguar probably is. Jaguar is dangerous predator that can easily kill you in early game, for some time you literally watching your backs travelling around and try to learn where in the jungle they hunt so you can avoid surprise attack. Sounds cool right? Later you learn the how to capture one, so obviously you want one right? It's not only not easy in terms of game mechanics you need to learn, but also risky. So you finally captured Jaguar one day. A dangerous predator on your side? Nope. A "horse". Jaguar once tamed is only a mount. Soulmask is filled with such put-hours-of-gameplay for a meh reward content. 

There is a lot of content in Soulmask, but the more content you come across, the more discouraged you are to push further due to way the content is implemented. Like I said, it's checklist content, implemented sometimes in most unimaginative, lazy way just to be there instead of have any meaningful impact on a gameplay. 
What would be acceptable for an Early Access game knowing the meh stuff might turn into good stuff when developers expand on it after players feedback. But we already know it won't happen in case of Soulmask so lazy, unimaginative content is all you get. But hey, there's a lot of it, so I guess for some it makes it okay-ish?

DLC seems promising tho, so you know. There's a hope.

In every way EXCEPT GPU load, this is a great game.  There are pathing bugs and some minor gameplay bugs, but overall, I would have rated this a positive except for one thing.

This game does not run well on an RTX 2060.  Nor does it run particularly well on an RTX 3050.

As with most modern games, Soulmask suffers from a lack of optimization of the primary graphics rendering thread in the client.
This means if you want to enable any setting (grass, shadows, distance, textures, particle effects, etc) other than the minimum, your GPU load will be 100% constantly, no matter the GPU you have in your rig.

So, given you are going to play this game for hours, that means the temperature of the card will exceed 91'C for hours and hours and hours.  Again, only if you want to play on any setting other than the minimum.

If you're willing to limit your framerate to 30 or 45 FPS, your card will run cooler.  It's a terrible shame to have to do this, given how beautiful the game can look, but that's the reality as of Sept 18, 2025.
Hopefully before 1.0 release, the developers of Soulmask fix both the pathing bugs and the GPU optimization, and they will have a game worthy of the price tag.

Until then, caveat emptor, and be ready to enjoy the sound of a GPU FAN running at 100%. :D

The game kinda sells you on a system in which you can automate the boring wood, stone gathering etc - allowing you to assign these tasks and base upkeep to your NPC Tribesmen.

"Gee-Willikers, that sure is awesome...now I can spend more time exploring the massive sprawling world!"
No Billy.

First, you have tasks to complete which are intended to teach you the game.
Don't worry though Billy, because later, this will all become too much information and you'll soon need to relearn everything from a YouTuber that can explain it far clearer.
Then, you need to capture a slave....
Just fight your way through a camp, spare one and stare menacingly into their eyes until they submit and go into a coma. (you know - the usual "How I met your mother" story).
Next, caveman-carry them back to your base and throw them lifelessly onto a bed.
Then, literally spoon-feed them until they regain consciousness, at which point I assume you’ve either gaslit them into cooperation or they have the fastest case of Stockholm syndrome ever.
Either way - you own them now.

Now comes the fun part.
Now, you'll have to navigate possibly the most convoluted AI task assignment process known to man.
But fret not Billy ol chum...after getting the hang of this, doing your taxes won't feel so bad.
Things will also constantly go wrong with the orders you have given your tribe, so don’t think you're out into the woods just yet.
Next, you have to manage their inventories to ensure they don't starve or die.
Then, you need to ensure you continue to build more storage constantly.
Oh, and don't forget to keep an eye out on the durability of their tools.

Now, its finally time.
Time to d-d-d- dua...er I mean, go to sleep, to manage your sanity, cook some food and gather water for yourself - and your tribe.
Lest your slaves turn against you and leave because yes...there is a mood bar, and several other fun and exciting meters to monitor to ensure happiness is felt by all.

In every way EXCEPT GPU load, this is a great game.  There are pathing bugs and some minor gameplay bugs, but overall, I would have rated this a positive except for one thing.

This game does not run well on an RTX 2060.  Nor does it run particularly well on an RTX 3050.

As with most modern games, Soulmask suffers from a lack of optimization of the primary graphics rendering thread in the client.
This means if you want to enable any setting (grass, shadows, distance, textures, particle effects, etc) other than the minimum, your GPU load will be 100% constantly, no matter the GPU you have in your rig.

So, given you are going to play this game for hours, that means the temperature of the card will exceed 91'C for hours and hours and hours.  Again, only if you want to play on any setting other than the minimum.

If you're willing to limit your framerate to 30 or 45 FPS, your card will run cooler.  It's a terrible shame to have to do this, given how beautiful the game can look, but that's the reality as of Sept 18, 2025.
Hopefully before 1.0 release, the developers of Soulmask fix both the pathing bugs and the GPU optimization, and they will have a game worthy of the price tag.

Until then, caveat emptor, and be ready to enjoy the sound of a GPU FAN running at 100%. :D

In its current state, the game is just… meh. It has potential, but right now it didn’t really pull me in. I was hoping for something along the lines of Conan, but unfortunately it’s not that.

I know it’s a survival game and it’s still in early access, but starting out with no real goal besides a flood of tutorials and information—even the UI is overwhelming at first—can easily push players away. There’s no real introduction to the story (if there even is one). And that opening cutscene? For me, it explains absolutely nothing. I get that it’s a survival game, but many survival games still have some kind of story setup, world introduction, or at least an explanation of who you are and why you're even here.

The crafting menu also isn’t great. I appreciate the attempt to divide knowledge into “sections,” but it doesn’t help much when you’re still being flooded with a massive list of items. It would be much better if everything was separated into clearly defined windows/categories.

The animations are so stiff it’s honestly painful to look at. The transitions between them… ugh. Just try chopping a tree and moving your mouse—the character suddenly “teleports” into a new position. Or if your character dies underwater, they start crawling. Crawling! Underwater. The same goes for facial expressions: there basically aren’t any, and characters look like empty dolls.

Combat is also pretty mediocre. The animations aren’t great (same issue as above), and enemies feel super stiff too—they mostly just stare at you, waiting for you to make a move, and sometimes they hit you… maybe. In most games, combat feels enjoyable to me, but here it really doesn’t.

I even jumped into the water expecting some sharks or something interesting, but nope—just empty space where you can swim and swim and swim and… swim.

As for graphics, they’re nice and pleasant to look at. I enjoyed running around the map, but that leads to another issue: the map is big, but mostly empty, aside from a few animals. (Maybe that’s because I didn’t explore much beyond the starting zone, but honestly the game didn’t motivate me to go further.) Most of my time was spent running around aimlessly.

Now, the character creator… look, I know it’s early access, but considering how extremely limited it is, it’s hard to say anything positive. But hey, they added jiggle physics for breasts… Great right... I guess. Personally, in actual state I’d prefer just two preset characters—one male and one female—but actually well polished. Maybe the character creator will improve later and give us more options.

There’s also no first-person mode. If I can’t make my character look the way I want, then I’d rather not stare at her and would prefer a first-person view instead.

The building mode is a so much pain. There’s absolutely no button to lower or raise foundations — you have to dance around to position things properly and wiggle the camera. When i love building in almost every game, that here. No way!

So overall, the game didn’t grab my attention or hook me enough with its beginning for me to want to come back to it. Maybe I’ll give it another try someday when I run out of other games to play, but for now… it’s just boring.

If you're looking for an MMO/Co-op experience similar to Conan, Ark, or Rust, this will probably deliver everything you're hoping for. My review is only based on the solo experience.

Even though it is designed similarly to the aforementioned MMO/co-op games, Soulmask boasts having theoretically hyper-capable AI followers that can practically run your base for you without ever having to lift a finger yourself. While it's true that they *can* do just about any task players can do, they're not incredibly intelligent about it. You'll constantly have to reset or modify their orders to avoid having them do nothing but rest around your campfire, which kind of defeats the purpose of having them do the work for you.

And don't even think about depending on them in combat. Sure, they can fight off the random animal or raider you encounter while exploring the world, but actual quest areas, dungeons, and bosses were clearly designed with a party of players in mind. AI followers absolutely cannot substitute for real, thinking players here, and if you try to take these challenges on by yourself with only a few followers at your back, you'll just get everyone killed and lose hours of work you put into strengthening and gearing up.
